So remember with regards to the tails, size and location is crucial. We have invisible tails as well as sort of open and extreme tails. Now the important thing to understand is that the larger the tail, the larger the level of conviction or strength is at that given point. Equally, the larger the tail, the more significant the point is or the price is that we are rejecting or moving away from. as well as, obviously, where does that tail occur, alright? A tail in the middle of a trade location in a balanced area is far less significant than a tail formed when we are out of balance or in non-symmetrical type days. So, very crucial to interpret where is the location of the tail, but also what is the size. In terms of value area overlap, how much overlap do we get between yesterday's value area or where the market accepted price and where the market is accepting price today? Again, markets that are overlapping a lot of value area will tend to continue to do that until we get some market moving information, whereas if there's a lack of overlap in value areas, this could be showing us high potential for one time framing on a day-to-day basis. So again, understanding how much overlap we get within the value area is crucial. Then again, low volume errors and high volume errors, both crucial control identifiers. Low volume errors show us strength, or stronger control variables, whereas high volume errors show us less strength. Time.

Just remember, the less time a market takes to effectively accept or reject something, it's showing us one thing versus if a market is taking more time. Again, time regulates the opportunity. Don't forget to always interpret your strategies in terms of time. But some strategies should take relatively little time to play out and some strategies should take a long time. So again, if it comes counter to the principle, make sure you're interpreting this because this can be an early identifier for a potential of the failure of the strategy and even potential for reversal of the strategy. And then lastly, or second to last, if a market spends a long time at an important juncture point, the longer time spent reflects an increasing probability of failure. Just like we said, time regulates the opportunity. So time is a great barometer for conviction and confidence. Again, take for example when we spoke about initiative. There should be relatively little time when a market initiates and accepts to initiating again. If a market initiates and then spends a long, long time balancing out, it's highly likely that we've seen the end of this initiation, at least for the given time frame. So again, time will regulate each one of the opportunities and strategies you develop. time provides the signal and the structure that we've developed with the volume profile provides the confirmation.
